docs.abstract: Crash Ruskin on-line comment, as college student from New Jersey suburb, on April 9 article about Long Beach, New York, and its young people (S)
docs.snippet: We asked online readers of our special issue on the suburbs whether they preferred the city or the suburbs. Here is one response from , a New York Times Web site at www.abuzz.com.      When I read Charlie LeDuff's article on Long Beach and its kid...
docs.lead_paragraph: We asked online readers of our special issue on the suburbs whether they preferred the city or the suburbs. Here is one response from , a New York Times Web site at www.abuzz.com. When I read Charlie LeDuff's article on Long Beach and its kids, two things kept going through my mind: ''This can't be how they see themselves,'' followed by, ''That sounds like home.''

headline.main: A Record Shop Where Customers Rival the Collection

docs.snippet: TIM JACKSON shrank nervously as he recalled the time Courtney Love, the lead singer for the rock group Hole and Kurt Cobain's widow, walked into Adult Crash, the record store that he opened with his girlfriend, Carolyn Schmitt, last August.    "We...
docs.lead_paragraph: TIM JACKSON shrank nervously as he recalled the time Courtney Love, the lead singer for the rock group Hole and Kurt Cobain's widow, walked into Adult Crash, the record store that he opened with his girlfriend, Carolyn Schmitt, last August. "We had the National Enquirer article that showed Evan Dando and Courtney Love kissing taped to the window facing outside," he said. "She came in, shopped, bought some stuff, walked by the counter really fast and said sarcastically, 'Nice window display.' "

docs.abstract: Patrick Turner's plans for Crash Cafe, theme restaurant where train, plane and car wrecks would be displayed, upsets residents of Baltimore's nearby historic neighborhoods, as well as Gail A Dunham, president of National Air Disaster Alliance (Baltimore Journal) (S)

headline.main: Baltimore Journal; Mixing Mayhem and Fun Upsets a Neighborhood

docs.snippet: The spectacle of thousands of people watching city officials implode a decrepit high-rise public housing building, as they did here a few years ago, fascinated Patrick Turner. So does the notion that drivers routinely slow down to see a grisly acc...
docs.lead_paragraph: The spectacle of thousands of people watching city officials implode a decrepit high-rise public housing building, as they did here a few years ago, fascinated Patrick Turner. So does the notion that drivers routinely slow down to see a grisly accident. ''People like dramatic themes,'' Mr. Turner said today, standing in the cavernous hulk of a failed bar in south Baltimore that he intends to convert into the Crash Cafe, a culinary monument to mayhem.

docs.abstract: Crash Davis, obscure 1940's infielder who emerged as something of celebrity when Kevin Costner became his namesake playing shrewd but fading minor leaguer in movie Bull Durham, dies at 82; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Crash Davis, an obscure 1940's infielder who emerged as something of a celebrity when Kevin Costner became his namesake playing a shrewd but fading minor leaguer in the movie ''Bull Durham,'' died last Friday at his home in Greensboro, N.C. He was...
docs.lead_paragraph: Crash Davis, an obscure 1940's infielder who emerged as something of a celebrity when Kevin Costner became his namesake playing a shrewd but fading minor leaguer in the movie ''Bull Durham,'' died last Friday at his home in Greensboro, N.C. He was 82. He had cancer, his family said.

docs.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Crash, directed by Paul Haggis and starring Don Cheadle and Jennifer Esposito; photo (M)

headline.main: Bigotry as the Outer Side of Inner Angst

docs.snippet: Americans from radically different backgrounds are brought together by a grim serendipity in Paul Haggis's frustrating directorial debut....
docs.lead_paragraph: What kind of movie is ''Crash''? It belongs to a genre that has been flourishing in recent years -- at least in the esteem of critics -- but that still lacks a name. A provisional list of examples might include ''Monster's Ball,'' ''House of Sand and Fog'' and ''21 Grams.'' In each of these films, as in ''Crash,'' Americans from radically different backgrounds are brought together by a grim serendipity that forces them, or at least the audience, to acknowledge their essential connectedness. The look of these movies and the rough authenticity of their locations create an atmosphere of naturalism that is meant to give force to their rigorously pessimistic view of American life. The performances, often by some of the finest screen actors working today, have the dense texture and sober discipline that we associate with realism. But to classify these movies as realistic would be misleading, as the stories they tell are, in nearly every respect, preposterous, and they tend to be governed less by the spirit of observation than by superstition.
